concept.title: Attributes
concept.shortdesc: In TokenScript, by defining attributes, token data becomes available to Cards and Websites

conbody.p: In TokenScript you can declare “attributes”. These are properties of the token.
TokenScript does not define or assume any specific token attributes, merely that any token must have at least one attribute.

The most commonly used attribute is "balance" as defined in ERC20. Let's take another more complex example, for a token represents a ticket for a soccer match, its attributes should contain the information when and where the match happens, which teams play, which seat is reserved and so on. If the token allows you to lease a car, it needs an attribute like “expiry”.
Attributes are declared in TokenScript. The following is a minimalist declaration, where an attribute "balance" is defined. The value originates from an Ethereum function call balanceOf.
An token attribute is defined, so that the TokenScript engine knows how to get its value when needed.
Once defined, the attribute is available to all of the defined for this token in the same TokenScript file without special permissions. It also became available in the to allow functionalities like:

ul.li: Search / index of a token (e.g. in a market place)
Set the role of a token.

conbody.p: An token's attribute is a data object.

Attributes are just declarations. They are never directly shown to a wallet. They are just here to let the wallet know and to allow TokenScript to build further operations and representations on it. To make them visible you need cards.
Attribute is a categorical declaration. There are other declarations inside the <attribute> tags, for example <origins> or <token>.
If you TokenScript wants to querry an API for information, like weather or exchange prices, this will not be part of the attribute tag, but part of an action card.
